questions.question: He talked as if he ………………….. everything, but he didn’t.
questions.description: After as if and as though we use a past tense with a  present meaning to show that a comparison is unreal.

questions.question: ……………………….. in Germany, I got to befriend a musician.
questions.description: The sentence can also be written as: While he was in Germany… This structure is not possible with as.

questions.question: You look ………………………….. you are about to cry.
questions.description: We can use as if and as though to say what a situation seems like.

questions.question: ……………………. I was a child, I stayed with my grandparents.
questions.description: We use when to refer to periods of life.

questions.question: Don’t ask me ………………………
questions.description: To ask for something is to ask somebody to give something.

questions.question: James, as well as, Janet ……………………… excited to hear the news.
questions.description: When we connect two subjects with as well as, the verb is singular when the first subject is singular.

questions.question: I answered all the questions ………………………. one.
questions.description: But can mean except after all.

questions.question: Nobody but ………………………. would do a thing like that.
questions.description: Object pronouns are more common after but. Subject pronouns are possible in a formal style.

questions.question: The car is too …………………….. for the garage.
questions.description: We use wide to talk about the physical distance from one side of something to the other.

questions.question: You ………………………. write good English in a few months.
questions.description: We use will be able to to talk about future ability.

questions.question: I wish that I …………………….. prettier.
questions.description: In that-clauses after wish we normally use a past tense with a present or future meaning. In a formal style, were is possible instead of was in this structure.

questions.question: Don’t fight ……………………. him – he is much bigger than you.
questions.description: After fight, quarrel, argue, struggle and play, 'with' can be used with the same meaning as against.
